node.title: Installation problem On HPC
node.bodyText:
Dear Everyone,
Happy new year!
My name is Xiaojing, I am trying to install moose on our HPC, but I got 14 tests failed, I can still generate my executable(opt) files. I am writing to ask whether the failing tests will influence my simulation performance.
you can see the failed process in the following picture:

Warm regards,
Xiaojing

If you scroll up in your window you will have the complete error messages for each test. Take a look at those error messages and see if there is something consistent between them and share that information.

Thank you so much for your reply, I added my test-log file below.
log-tests.txt

There's a variety of errors. Looks like you don't have matplotlib installed.
There's some MPI and Petsc errors too. How did you install petsc ?

Thank you for your answer, I noticed there is a lot of errors after I install Moose on HPC.  I am using a system-wide installation provided by the HPC team.  They download petsc(3.11.1) from: https://ftp.mcs.anl.gov/pub/petsc/release-snapshots/
and install it.  Will these errors influence the performance of the simulation?
Because I tried to use partitioner in my code: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Mesh/Partitioner/index.html#!
It seems the performance is not improving when I add a partitioner. I feel curious about whether I did something wrong when I install moose. Hope you can give me some suggestions on how to figure this out.
Thank you for your help

Hi.
I have installed MOOSE on our machine so that our users can compile their own work in their local directories. To build MOOSE, I use the pre-installed PETSc module; everything is compiled (consistently?) using FOSS 2018a toolchain (i.e. with OpenMPI 2.1.2). However, I have the flexibility to recompile MOOSE (and its dependencies) using more recent toolchains, if that might make a performance difference.
I have attached the build script used for the current version, so, I appreciated if you give a look, and let me know if anything can be improved.
moose.zip

Additions:

For your missing matplotlib dependency (On Tier-1 skylake partition), you can use matplotlib/3.1.1-intel-2018a-Python-3.7.2 module, which is compatible with the Python dependency version
In the error log you sent, I see the error: PETSC ERROR: Could not locate solver package superlu_dist. Perhaps you must ./configure with --download-superlu_dist. I suspected that SUPERLU was missing from PETSc package
I inspected the build logs of the used module PETSc/3.11.1-foss/2018a, and searched for results of SUPERLU test; Indeed, SUPERLU is installed as part of PETSc, and is tested during the build time; see e.g. /apps/leuven/skylake/2018a/software/PETSc/3.11.1-foss-2018a/share/petsc/examples/src/snes/examples/tutorials/output/ex19_superlu.out
The same is true for the Cholesky solver
I checked the group permissions on the PETSc folder, and I realized that it needed some fix.

Would you please try again with your tests?
Thank you very much for your help, i will test it and see whether it helps

node.title: Continue forward simulation
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts,
I would like to ask, can moose continue to simulate forward at the time of the previous simulation instead of re-simulating?
In detail, if I set the time as follows:
  start_time = 0.0   end_time = 8000 
After the simulation is completed, I set ent_time = 10000, but hope that start_time = 8001. Does moose have such a function?
If so, how can I do it?
Any suggestions or recommendations to fix these problems would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you
Wei Peng
You need to add checkpoint = true in your Outputs block in your first run and then start your second run with --recover after increasing the end time.

Thank you for your reply, the problem is solved.
Follow your suggestion, Following your suggestion, I solved the problem in two steps:
First add "checkpoint = true" to the outputs block in the input file.
After the simulation is complete, modify the end_time, and finally run the name command line "*-opt -i *.i --recover".

Dear dschwen,
Regarding the function of this moose, I still have some questions and hope to get your suggestion.
First, I use recover to run grain_growth_2D_graintracker.i, it can continue to simulate forward. @dschwen
But when I change the input file to poly_grain_growth_2D_eldrforce.i, it shows an error in the terminal, the error is as follows:
*** ERROR ***
ERROR: Neither one of the following files can be located:
'_mesh.cpr/1/header.cpr' nor
'_mesh.cpr'
If you are running a parallel job, double check that you've created a split for 1 ranks.
Note: One of paths above may refer to a valid directory on your system, however we are attempting to read a valid header file.

For the coupled model of multiple physics modules, do I need to perform other operations to continue the forward simulation?
Have a read of https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/restart_recover.html to see if it satisfies your requirements.
Thank you for your quick reply, the webpage you gave is very important to me.

node.title: Petsc Has Not Been Detected
node.bodyText:
For this instance, I used the offline instructions to setup and install moose. When I go to run the test Makefile the following error is given:
"#error PETSc has not been detected, please ensure your environment is set up properly then rerun the libmesh build script and try to compile MOOSE again."
However, I appear to have the proper PETSC and LIBMESH path in my environment.
"echo$PETSC_DIR "returns "spack/opt/spack/linux-fedora33-skylake/gcc-8.4.0/petsc-3.14.1-k3f2iiz7zaifdrdr5bdjwih6nun3lxn3"
Which is the proper path on my machine.
Any ideas?
Did you run ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh already to build libmesh? How did you build PETSc (using  ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh)?

I haven't run either. I'm attempting to set up Moose to run on the package manager Spack (https://spack.io/). So it's been a very, shall we say, custom installation process. Attempting to run the ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh just now returns an error regarding no file or directory. I believe it is looking under the submodule libmesh. However, running "echo$LIBMESH_DIR" reveals the proper file path.
Did you follow these instructions carefully? https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/offline_installation.html

More or less. Spack takes the moose tarball and extracts it to a directory. Then inside of the package for spack, we specify dependencies such as libmesh and petsc. Spack will then extract and install libmesh and petsc to the same directory moose is installed. Inside of the petsc and libmesh dependencies are specified and also installed in the same directory as everything else. The PATHS are automatically specified. The only step that I've struggled to incorporate is the update_and_rebuild. Hopefully, this makes sense... I should mention the goal is to make this an automatic process so all a user has to do is "spack install moose" and then all the user needs to do is run ./PATH/TO/MOOSE/scripts/stork.sh AppName

Hmm. It seems like you're trying to setup a development environment for people on your HPC.
In a HPC environment, I'm much more a fan of giving users the base envs (mpich, cmake, python, more or less) and having them build PETSc and libMesh. Reason being, with the continuous changes that come with MOOSE, we update libMesh and PETSc in a regular manner. The preferred practice then is for users to manage their apps on their own with a moose submodule, which could vastly change which versions of PETSc and libMesh they need.
An alternative would be to provide PETSc, $PETSC_DIR, and $PETSC_ARCH, which changes far less often than libMesh, and then have them build their own libMesh.
This is just my $0.02. I can see some validity to actually providing a compiled MOOSE for users and having them update it as your admins update it. Internally, we use spack and modules for all of our build machines. For INL's HPC services, we provide the base compiler spack and PETSc (although we're considering transitioning away from that) via spack and modules and have users (developers) compiler libMesh.
Can you share the output of of the configure call for libMesh?

INFO: LIBMESH_DIR set - overriding default installed path
INFO: No cleaning will be done in specified path
./scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh: line 151: /home/las_djorton/spack/opt/spack/linux-fedora33-skylake/gcc-8.4.0/moose-20-10-27-fch3jy6pi5r5htldeik5pevjzuzqoizt/scripts/../libmesh/configure: No such file or directory
make: *** No targets specified and no makefile found.  Stop.

spack is able to have set LIBMESH_DIR as it does for PETSC_DIR? If you have libmesh and PETSc installed correctly via spack, then you do NOT need to run update_and_rebuild_libmesh/petsc.sh.
I think the problem right now is that spack did not set LIBMESH_DIR, and MOOSE can not figure out where libmesh is.
Set LIBMESH_DIR to point to libmesh, and then recompile moose again

@fdkong I do appreciate your tip, however, I've already attempted this and it has not solved the problem. I do like that you confirmed my original thought (that the setup steps are redundant in spack) however I still have the issue of it not finding the correct PATH. However, when I check the PATH that is listed (I run the cmd $LIBMESH_DIR and $PETSC_DIR to check the path) the PATH is correct. Thus my confusion. Additionally, I would like to mention I have the PETSC and LIBMESH modules loaded. Still I get the error:
"""/home/spack/opt/spack/linux-fedora33-skylake/gcc-8.4.0/moose-20-10-27-ithupfgwabwausyf3ygn7lutwbskvd73/framework/build/header_symlinks/Moose.h:235:2: error: #error PETSc has not been detected, please ensure your environment is set up properly then rerun the libmesh build script and try to compile MOOSE again.
#error PETSc has not been detected, please ensure your environment is set up properly then rerun the libmesh build script and try to compile MOOSE again.
"""
"""
/home/spack/opt/spack/linux-fedora33-skylake/gcc-8.4.0/moose-20-10-27-ithupfgwabwausyf3ygn7lutwbskvd73/framework/build/header_symlinks/DualReal.h:17:10: fatal error: metaphysicl/metaphysicl_version.h: No such file or directory
#include "metaphysicl/metaphysicl_version.h"
"""
I figured out the reason this wasn't working was LIbmesh was not finding petsc but the moose package was. I had to specify within my libmesh install the path to petsc.

node.title: How to apply ICs on the boundary
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
We plan to simulate the directional solidification in a 2D region.  We took the snow.i as the ref input code for our study.  We assume that  the solidification occur first near the bottom line.  For this purpose, we write the code as follows,
[ICs]
[./wIC]
type = MultiSmoothCircleIC
invalue = 1
outvalue = 0
radius = 0.05
radius_variation_type=uniform
radius_variation=0.01
variable = w
numbub = 6
bubspac = 1.0
boundary = left
[../]
[]
But I found no solidification and no temperature change during simulations.
How should we edit this section.  Thanks very much.

The snow.i example assumes uniform undercooling in a liquid composed of a pure material, and does not include a fixed temperature gradient as would normally be required to simulate directional solidification. So just be aware that the physics you are trying to simulate may not be captured by this input file. We have some work to develop an alloy directional solidification example which should be coming this year sometime.
As far as inserting nuclei in your initial conditions block, it looks like you are trying to put solid seeds on a certain boundary by specifying boundary = left. That option doesn't do what you want. What I would do instead is use SpecifiedSmoothCircleIC and manually specify the (x,y) positions where you want each solid seed to be placed. Then run for 1 time step and make sure the solid seeds are where you want them before running the simulation out to longer times.

Thank you for your reminder. Because I just started working with moose code, I now try to get familiar with it by modifying some of the blocks and parameters in the phase_field module based on some examples in the codes .

node.title: Negative Jacobian - contact in cylindrical tank
node.bodyText:
I am building a model of a cylindrical tank filled with water in 3D. Frictionless contact is defined at all surfaces between the water and the tank. When running the input file attached (I replaced the water constitutive model I have with a simple elastic model), it fails in the first time step stating that there is a negative jacobian in a Quad 4 element. I have double checked the mesh file several times and it only contains hex 8 elements. I am wondering how to fix this issue for this specific geometry.
I have tried different geometry and it only works when the thickness of the tank is increased. Also, it works if the contact block is commented out.
3D_tank_error.zip

Based on the error message, it looks like the error is related to the bottom contact surface (coord_z = -0.496 should be your bottom surface). Secondly, the error says that ''ERROR: negative Jacobian -2.06795e-25 at point (x,y,z)=(-0.0149897, -0.10797,   -0.496) in element 4294967295". That ID number is wired to me.
I took a closer look at your mesh, and I believe there are some issues with your tank block mesh. To me, the bottom and the side are separate meshes, and not connected correctly.

node.title: Peacock colorbar is not showing correctly
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose Team,
I wanted to use moose for future simulations and now learning some basics.
When I visualize the result from example01 in peacock, my colorbar is fully black:

How could I fix this problem?
Thanks for the help.
Regards,
Hao
Are you using a Virtual Machine? If so, this is a known problem that we are unsure how to fix.
Yes, I am using a VM on my Windows, thanks for the answer, I will need to reinstall moose on a proper ubuntu system.
Paraview should work if you need something quick in the VM.
Thanks, paraview would be a good temp solution for VM.

node.title: control global strain
node.bodyText:
Hello all,
I am using Phase Field + Tensor Mechanics to simulate phase transformation. In my model, there is local elastic strain and the global strain should be zero. How can I control the global strain to be zero?
Thank you very much
Best regards
Li

@LiWen-HUST
Dear Li Wen,
your question is not very clear.
I believe you mean that you want zero macroscopic strain in a representative volume.
To achieve that, you can set zero displacement boundary conditions on all boundaries.
Best Regards,
Nicolò Grilli
National University of Singapore
That's my question. Thank you very much!

node.title: Min GCC version ?
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I noticed that there has been a change to the min gcc version. Does this mean that moose will not compile with gcc 4.8.5 ?? I have not tried and I am not sure if i should
The minimum supported gcc version has been bumped to 5.1.0. This does not necessarily mean that it will not compile with 4.8.5... but that we don't officially support it.
Will try and get back soon.

I recall that i faced some issues compiling the newer version of MOOSE with
GCC 7.0 (in a recent build on CSD3). With lower versions, say, GCC 4.8.5,
it did build OK, but the test suite failed. May be it could be related to
the version of MPI loaded in the environment. But the good thing is that my
actual inelastic cases are pretty much up and running.

node.title: Crash experienced running run_tests
node.bodyText:
This may be a simple problem.  I am installing MOOSE for the first time on a Windows 10 machine using CONDA and I get all the way to the test part.  When I get to testing it using the "run_tests" command, I run into the following error (see below).  I see two information: 1) libquadmath.so.0 is not being found, and 2) the test reports a crash (something about oversized).  I am not sure I completely understand the information and how to search specifically for this issue on the discussion forum to help resolve it.  Help to guide to resolve this problem or a pointer to another discussion question which may help me is appreciated.
(moose) nat1840@TC-D900675:/projects/moose/test$ make -j 8
(moose) nat1840@TC-D900675:/projects/moose/test$ ./run_tests -i always_ok -p 2
tests/test_harness.always_ok: Working Directory: /home/nat1840/projects/moose/test/tests/test_harness
tests/test_harness.always_ok: Running command: mpiexec -n 2 /home/nat1840/projects/moose/test/moose_test-opt -i good.i --error --error-unused --error-override --no-gdb-backtrace
tests/test_harness.always_ok: /home/nat1840/projects/moose/test/moose_test-opt: error while loading shared libraries: libquadmath.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
tests/test_harness.always_ok: /home/nat1840/projects/moose/test/moose_test-opt: error while loading shared libraries: libquadmath.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
tests/test_harness.always_ok:
tests/test_harness.always_ok:
tests/test_harness.always_ok: Exit Code: 127
tests/test_harness.always_ok: ################################################################################
tests/test_harness.always_ok: Tester failed, reason: CRASH
tests/test_harness.always_ok:
tests/test_harness.always_ok ...................................................... [OVERSIZED] FAILED (CRASH)
Final Test Results:
tests/test_harness.always_ok ...................................................... [OVERSIZED] FAILED (CRASH)
Ran 1 tests in 0.9 seconds.
0 passed, 0 skipped, 0 pending, 1 FAILED
(moose) nat1840@TC-D900675:~/projects/moose/test$

I just ran into this exact same problem today. I was able to get MOOSE to build and run by manually installing gcc, which contains the libquadmath library.
Try "sudo apt install gcc", then clean out and rebuild MOOSE (i.e., do a "make clean", then "make -j4" in the test directory). That worked for me, so it might solve your problem.
Thank you.  That took care of the issue.
